displaytitle: Phidias, study for the South Court Mosaics, Victoria and Albert Museum, London
creditline: Gift of the Forbes Magazine Collection: Malcolm S. Forbes, Class of 1941, Malcolm S. Forbes, Jr., Class of 1970, and Christopher Forbes, Class of 1972
inscribed:
In black watercolor, center: PHIDIAS.
In brown ink, lower right: 18 EJP 64

makers.displaydate: 1836–1919; born Paris, France; died London, England
makers.displaymaker: Sir Edward John Poynter, 1836–1919; born Paris, France; died London, England

texts.textentryhtml: Phidias, the renowned ancient Greek sculptor, is shown holding a mallet and chisel in one hand and a statue of the goddess Athena in the other, with the Parthenon in the background. Poynter created this highly finished watercolor study for one of thirty-five monumental paintings representing celebrated painters, sculptors, architects, and decorative artists from antiquity through the eighteenth century; these, in turn, were made into glass and ceramic mosaics. The designs were commissioned from Poynter and other British painters for the South Court of the South Kensington Museum (later the Victoria and Albert Museum), where the mosaics remained on view from the 1870s until 1949.
The Fine Art Society Ltd., (no. 16822, March 1980), printed label on old frame backing.
texts.remarks: As per Giada Damen, IMLS Drawings 2018-2020

bibliography.boilertext: "Acquisitions of the Art Museum 1985," Record of the Art Museum, Princeton University 45, no. 1 (1986): p.16–42
